IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: The College delivers unique Master of Science degrees in Impact-Focused Business Investing, Sustainable Fashion and Risk, Resilience and Integrity Management.
IRS990.MissionDesc: As New York City's College for the Common Good, GCNYC offers Master of Science degrees that prepare students to be enterprising, compassionate leaders in social impact, sustainable fashion and risk management. Guided by knowledge and experienced faculty, students learn to re-imagine business within the context of the UN Sustainable Development Goals, balancing profitability with the well-being of communities and the planet.
IRS990.Desc: M.S. Impact-Focused Business and Investing, Sustainable Fashion and Risk and Resilience and Integrity Management. During the fiscal year 2022/23 the College undertook 3 semesters in September 22, January 23 and April 23.

OtherLiabilitiesOrgGrp.Desc: Revolving loan payable to Sole Member

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part X, Line 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Under GAAP, an organization must recognize a tax liability associated with tax positions taken for tax-return purposes when it is more likely than not that the position will not be sustained upon examination by a taxing authority. The College does not believe it has taken any material uncertain tax positions and, accordingly, it has not recorded any liability for unrecognized tax benefits. The College has filed all tax returns, as required. For the year ended July 31, 2023, there were no interest or penalties recorded or included in the accompanying statements of activities.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule E, Part I, Line 3
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Glasgow Caledonian New York College does not discriminate on the basis of race, colour, creed, religion, national origin, disability, political affiliation, age, sexual orientation, arrest record, veteran or marital status in its education programs or activities, including employment and admissions, (Metro New York).

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: At GCNYC we believe that education is an investment for a brighter future. Our institutional commitment to furthering our "For the Common Good" mission and our equally strong desire to build a diverse academic community made up of the most passionate students means that GCNYC makes every reasonable attempt to help qualified students. We are proud to offer merit-based Common Good scholarships up to $10,000, which require an essay to be submitted. The essay should discuss at least two United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and how the student plans on moving these goals forward in their professional and personal life.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 3
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The compensation of the related organisations (GCU) employees (who are trustees of GCNYC) is discussed and approved by the GCU Remuneration Committee who meet twice a year. The compensation of the GCNYC staff members is discussed and approved by the GCNYC board of trustees who meet three times a year.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part II
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Trustees of GCNYC are not compensated by the reporting organisation. Whilst some are compensated by the related organisation (GCU), this compensation is not related to their capacity as trustee of GCNYC. This is evidenced in the by-laws of the reporting organisation under Article III Board of Trustees Section 3.12 Compensation - Trustees shall not receive any compensation for their services on the board. Trustees shall be allowed reimbursement for reasonable expenses, on resolution of the board.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part III, Line 1
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Glasgow Caledonian New York College (the College) was incorporated in June 2017. The College, as per the incorporating documents, is an educational corporation provisionally chartered by the Regents of the University of the State of New York. The College is organized and operated exclusively for educational purposes and no part of the earnings of the College shall inure to the benefit of any individual. Founded by Glasgow Caledonian University (GCU), the University for the Common Good, the College leverages over 150 years of academic excellence to bring a distinctly global perspective to degree programs focused on profitable sustainability. The College delivers unique Master of Science (M.S.) degrees in Impact-Focused Business and Investing, Sustainable Fashion and Global Risk, Resilience, and Integrity Management, which can be completed on a full time or part time basis at the New York (NY) campus. The College has been awarded SEVP status which enables the recruitment of International students. Along with this accreditation, the College has also received Title IV accreditation enabling domestic US students to access Federal Loan Funding. During academic year 22/23, eleven students were successful in their application for funds. The College anticipates that this Title IV accreditation will continue to have a positive influence on home recruitment in future academic years. In addition to this, the College hosts an ongoing series of conversations, which bridge the worlds of fashion, media and sustainability. The events provide a platform for the showing of ideas, sharing of best practices, and highlighting of emerging trends.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part III, Line 4a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: M.S. Sustainable Fashion - Unique among college programs focusing on fashion, this course prepares students for leadership in transforming the business and creative strategies of the fashion industry to support sustainability, social equity, and ethical practice. Students registering on this program will learn the benefits of operating a business under a new paradigm, eschewing the singular goal of profit for shareholders and replacing that with the need to serve a wide range of stakeholders. Students in the fashion program will collaborate with partner companies and organizations. These partnerships are facilitated by the new Centre for Social Impact and Innovation, which provides a support network as well as collaborative research opportunities. M.S. Impact-Focused Business and Investing - The M.S. in Impact-Focused Business and Investing is designed to provide a solid foundation in business fundamentals from the corporate, entrepreneurial, non-profit and public sector perspectives. Changemakers - entrepreneurs and intrapreneurs alike - have always been attracted to opportunities that, to other people, might look like problems. Students in this program will learn how to design and develop solutions to these problems regardless of whether they are starting their own venture or working in a corporation, social enterprise, or non-profit organization. M.S. Risk, Resilience and Integrity Management - The unique Master's in Risk, Resilience and Integrity at Glasgow Caledonian New York College (GCNYC) has been designed for those who want to take a truly global, interdisciplinary and cross-sectoral approach to transforming the way any type of organization approaches risk management. This program will train students to see risk, resilience and integrity management as a key component of profitable sustainability and value-creation whether you are working or plan to work for a for-profit business, non-profit, government agency or multilateral institution. GCNYC offers both full- and part-time options at its beautiful location in SoHo, where students will build connections to industry experts each week. Students will work closely with a diverse cohort of fellow students and faculty with decades of experience to gain the global perspective, multi-industry knowledge and strategic leadership skills needed for a successful career. With a unique focus on risk, resilience and integrity as components of profitable sustainability, you'll learn to see how these functions can be an instrument of change - and a force for the common good.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 1b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Ian Kerr, Elinor Ruth Tatum, Daniel Bena, Laura Becking, Sylvie Freund-Pickavance, Jo-Ann Rolle, Eva Haller, Amit Bhargava, Neena Mahal and Euan Rellie (Trustees of GCNYC) are independent as they are remunerated by neither the filing organization nor the sole member (GCU).

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 3
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The related organisation (GCU) carries out various administrative functions of GCNYC. These include but are not limited to Treasury, Finance & Accounting and Human Resource support. These are managed internally by GCU and any issues arising are reported back the the Board of Trustees of GCNYC. As a result of this service provision, a charge is calculated at the end of the financial year based on the time spent by the different departments, and an invoice is raised to GCNYC for these services. The amount in question for 2022/23 was $45,485.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 6
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Under the organisations by-laws (Article II Membership Section 1) the sole member of GCNYC is the University Court of Glasgow Caledonian University (GCU), as incorporated under Article 3 of the Glasgow Caledonian University (Scotland) Order of Council 1993 and section 45(2) of the Further and Higher Education (Scotland) Act of 1992).

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 7a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Under the organisations by-laws (Article III Board of Trustees Section 3), the number of trustees shall be fixed from time to time by the member (GCU). The trustees shall be elected at the annual meeting of the member. A vacancy on the Board arising at any time and from any cause may be filled by the member. Any trustees may be removed with or without cause by the member.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 9
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The board of trustees (Professor Mike Mannion, Paul Brown, Ian Kerr, Elinor Ruth Tatum, Daniel Bena, Laura Becking, Sylvie Freund-Pickavance, Jo-Ann Rolle, Eva Haller, Amit Bhargava, Neena Mahal and Euan Rellie) can be contacted at the following address: GCNYC, 70 Cowcaddens Road, Glasgow, Scotland, G4 0BS, United Kingdom.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The board of trustees are the governing body of GCNYC. The Form 990 has been prepared by the Financial Accounting Manager in conjunction with the Governance and HR departments. It has been reviewed by professional advisors where appropriate and a copy of the return as will be filed with the IRS has been made available to all trustees in the papers circulated prior to the December 2023 board meeting. The Form 990 was discussed at this board meeting and duly signed thereafter.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The trustees of GCNYC are required to submit a register of interests form annually to Governance in accordance with the Register of Interests Policy. New board members, officers and key employees are also required to adhere to this policy prior to appointment.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The compensation of the GCNYC staff members is discussed and approved by the GCNYC board of trustees who meet three times a year.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Upon request GCNYC will provide Audited Financial Statements and in accordance with relevant Federal law, will provide copies of Tax Form 1023 Application for Recognition of Exemption Under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and the most recent Form 990 and 990-T. Requests can be made in writing to info@gcunewyork.com.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VII, Section A, Line 1a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The trustees of GCNYC are not compensated by the reporting organization GCNYC. Whilst they are compensated by related organization (GCU), this compensation is not related in any way to their capacity as trustee of GCNYC. This is evidenced by the by-laws of the reporting organization under Article III Board of Trustees Section 3.12 Compensation - Trustees shall not receive any compensation for their services on the board. Trustees shall be allowed reimbursement for reasonable expenses, on resolution of the Board.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule R, Part II
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The sole member of GCNYC is the University Court of Glasgow Caledonian University (GCU) as incorporated under Article 3 of the Glasgow Caledonian University (Scotland) Order of Council 1993 and Section 45(2) of the Further and Higher Education (Scotland) Act of 1992. As per Schedule R instructions, as a foreign organization, GCU has been recognized as a public charity based on the opinion that it is, in fact, the UK equivalent of a public charity.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule R, Part V, Line 1e
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Historically GCNYC had the ability to borrow under an unsecured revolving loan agreement which was in place with the sole member (GCU). This allowed for aggregate borrowing up to $30,700,000. The agreement temporarily suspends any repayment obligation when the College has a deficit in net assets. At July 31, 2023 an amount of $28,149,500 remained payable. Effective from fiscal year 2021, the College receives grant funding from GCU rather than further loan funding.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule R, Part V, Line 1o
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The related organization (GCU) carries out various administrative functions of GCNYC. As a result of this, a charge is calculated at the end of the financial year based on time spent by the different departments, and an invoice is raised to GCNYC for these services. The amount in question for 2022/23 falls below the reporting threshold ($45,485).
